intro: Grewia tembensis, commonly known as the African wild gooseberry, is a shrub native to tropical Africa. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its small, yellowish-orange fruits that resemble gooseberries. The plant typically grows in open woodlands and along riverbanks, thriving in well-drained soils. Its leaves are simple, alternate, and have a serrated margin, while its flowers are clustered and have five petals. The fruit is often used in traditional medicine and as a source of food for both humans and animals.
